column4: ```turtle@prefix rdfs: <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> .@prefix : <http://example.org/air#> .:Air a rdfs:Class ;  rdfs:label "Air" ;  rdfs:comment "The mixture of gases that surrounds the Earth and forms its atmosphere." .:Component a rdfs:Class ;  rdfs:label "Component" ;  rdfs:comment "The different gases that compose the air." .:Nitrogen a :Component ;  rdfs:label "Nitrogen" ;  rdfs:comment "Nitrogen gas, the most prevalent gas in air." .:Oxygen a :Component ;  rdfs:label "Oxygen" ;  rdfs:comment "Oxygen gas, essential for life processes." .:CarbonDioxide a :Component ;  rdfs:label "Carbon Dioxide" ;  rdfs:comment "Carbon Dioxide gas, a trace gas in air." .:Argon a :Component ;  rdfs:label "Argon" ;  rdfs:comment "Argon gas, another trace gas in air." .:AirComposition a rdfs:Property ;  rdfs:label "has component" ;  rdfs:domain :Air ;  rdfs:range :Component ;  rdfs:comment "The components or gases that make up air." .:Air rdfs:subClassOf  [ a rdfs:Restriction ;    rdfs:onProperty :AirComposition ;    rfs:allValuesFrom :Component ] .:Nitrogen rdfs:subClassOf :Component .:Oxygen rdfs:subClassOf :Component .:CarbonDioxide rdfs:subClassOf :Component .:Argon rdfs:subClassOf :Component .```In this example, we have created an ontology to describe air and its components. The classes represented are "Air" and "Component", and the specific components "Nitrogen", "Oxygen", "Carbon Dioxide" and "Argon". The property "has component" connects Air with the components it iscomposed of. The "AirComposition" filesystem property restricts the values of the "has component" domain to be instances of the "Component" class. Lastly, the specific gas components are all subclasses of the general "Component" class.
